According to a report by Bloomberg, Wells Fargo isn't sending restitution payments to victims of its numerous scandals fast enough, and regulators are apparently not happy with the progress the bank has made to change its culture.This is a big deal for a few reasons. First and foremost, Wells Fargo is still subject to the Federal Reserve penalty that stemmed from its scandals and essentially prevents the bank from growing. If regulators are unhappy with the bank's progress, this penalty could remain in place longer than investors expect.In addition, keep in mind that this is the first signal to indicate that regulators are unhappy with the bank's new management under CEO Charlie Scharf. Until now, regulators' anger has been entirely directed at the leaders in charge at the time the scandals were taking place.

Though the Fed kept the short-term rates unchanged this time, there has been increasing expectations of a rate hike as soon as in the second half of 2022. This, in turn, will support major banks' top-line growth. With banks' financials directly tied to the health of the economy, investors are now expecting improved profitability for major banks in the quarters ahead.

The company reported that, effective at the end of the day yesterday, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) consent order issued in September 2016 regarding the bank's retail sales practices had expired."The expiration of the CFPB's 2016 consent order is representative of progress we are making," Scharf said. "We have done substantial work designed to ensure that the conduct at the core of the consent order - which was reprehensible and wholly inconsistent with the values on which this company was built - will not recur."

There was a time when I almost respected the early "consumer care" views of Senator Warren. While I did not agree with the need for the CFPB to protect consumer interests, as other agencies were already filling that role and were focusing on improving performance, her views clearly had the consumer's interest center stage. But as time has progressed, Warren's views regarding "banking reform" have become less focused on the consumer and much more political in their intentions. She built her political career on "serving the consumer", but today's reality is she is using the consumer to serve her political views.

All the articles say Wells Fargo's problems started in 2016. They started long before that. In 2003 I took out a mortgage with a lender called Residential Mortgage. Within months Wells Fargo bought the bank and took over management of my mortgage. A month or so later I received a letter (not certified) saying my monthly payment had gone up over $400/month or I could make a deposit into escrow to cover the shortage. After inquiring why my escrow was short I was told is was because I had let my homeowners policy lapse so they took it upon themselves to insure the home and charge me the exorbitant amount. Here's the kicker. My annual homeowners policy had been paid in full at closing, and the loan was only months old. So I'm sitting there arguing over the phone ( w/ closing documents in my lap)with their representative and he's basically calling me a liar, saying they sent me a certified letter (which they hadn't). So while this is all going on I'm refusing to send in the extra amount and they're charging me a late fee every month. I had to go to my insurance company and get an affidavit of "proof of insurance" to finally resolve the matter. The insurance company said they had several complaints with the same issue with Wells Fargo. This has been going on for a long, long time. My ANNUAL homeowners was $1200, Wells Fargo was trying to charge me almost $5000 for the three month's left in the year.
Hope WFC bought some and more back this quarter while it was cheap.

The Algo-trade detects a negative news story on WFC and then it's off to the races....sell sell sell.The retail trader can actually read, digest and analyze the tangible impact of the story.... Option 1.. Story is bogus and nothing happensOption 2.. Story has a sliver of truth and WFC gets a nasty "Hurry Up" letter from regulatorsOption 3.. Story is true and regulators slap WFC on the wrist.Option 4.. Story is true and regulators attempt to make an example of WFC.The problem with Option 4 is WFC has already paid most of the fines out. It's not like regulators can argue WFC isn't making payments, they are just struggling to make final payments given they can't clearly identify individual's true harm.So what is the probability that Option 4 actually happens. I'd say 5%....10%... 2%..? Regulators aren't going to come in and jack up the penalties/fines by some insane $$ amount. At the end of the day this has little chance of being tangible and every chance of being a nothing story in a few days.Let the Algo-Trades sell it down and take advantage of your ability to reason.

Positive news...NEW YORK (Reuters) - Wells Fargo & Co(WFC) on Monday reached a $37.3 million settlement to resolve U.S. government accusations that it fraudulently overcharged hundreds of commercial customers who used its foreign exchange services.The settlement filed with the U.S. District Court in Manhattan requires a judge's approval, and resolves civil fraud charges against the fourth-largest U.S. bank.Wells Fargo (WFC) did not immediately respond to requests for comment. In afternoon trading, the bank's shares were down 2.1% at $46.91.The San Francisco-based bank has been dogged for the last five years by a series of scandals over its treatment of customers, and has been subjected since 2018 to a federal cap on asset growth until it improves its operations and oversight.According to court papers, Wells Fargo(WFC) defrauded 771 customers between 2010 and 2017 by systematically charging higher spreads or sales margins on foreign exchange transactions than it promised, and providing financial incentives to salespeople for the overcharges.(Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in New York; Editing by Mark Porter)

I am a big fan of WFC both as a long time customer and shareholder. But one thing they have done recently really puzzles me. I have a WFC credit card. I pay my balances off monthly automatically and I charge a fair amount so they make money on the merchant side. I have a very high credit score. I have a mortgage on an investment property with them that I have paid off almost 4 years early. I have multiple accounts and have been a customer for decades. But I get a letter about 2 months ago from them saying they won't let me keep my current credit card limit unless "I spend $4,000 on my card within the next 2 months". The funny thing is that I have a lot of cards and this one has one of the lower limits and I have never even been anywhere near the limit. But suddenly I have to spend $4K just to keep the same limit I have had for years with a spotless payment record? That seems very odd and just bad business. The kind of thing that makes long term customers says "bye-bye".

WFC certainly is an interesting, objective case study. And any WFC investor should certainly KNOW what they own and research its history. For years ... WFC was a strong, stable, long-term investment with a good divy, and well-respected among Financials and the broader market. Little did folks know the culture that was was breeding within their branches. That culture of fraud 1st came to light in late 2016 when the fake acct fraud 1st surfaced. WFC stock dropped, then languished a bit. Wells promised they would "make this right". And the market largely forgave them, as the stock, and the broader markets, performed well through 2017 with WFC reaching all-time highs. Then ... it was discovered that the scope of the fraud was MUCH deeper than originally disclosed, up to 4 Million fake accts. Plus it was discovered that 27,000 auto loan customers were were force-placed additional insurance premiums, when they already had coverage documented with the WFC loss-payee clause. This caused many to default, late fees, and damaging credit reports with massive $$$ damage to borrowers. Add another mortgage scandal ... and WFC stock tanked in Feb 2018 when regulators finally in posed sanctions. New investors looking for a quick buck, again drove the price up a bit. That's when I finally bolted at 57+ in Sept. 2018 after being a 20 yr investor. As more details of these scandals emerged, the precipitous decline of WFC stock continued through 2019. This at a time when other banks and the broader market saw 20%, 30% gains and more. WFC lost and sdditional 20% plus! Then ... the Covid paranoia in 2020, with WFC falling harder & faster than the rest of the market. In 2021, with more promises from WFC and the Covid paranoia subsiding, WFC investors did recover some of their losses, as the stock outperformed, which was somewhat predictable. of course nice gains in other Financials & the S&P also! :-). NOW ... adter all the fines, settlements, and sanctions; its discovered that WFC is not completing their restitution and obligations as they promised. Sound familiar? Be careful with this stock folks! Many investors & retirees lost massive $$$ on WFC the past 5 yrs. With the recent discovery, and Charlie remaining mumm, it doesn't look good! Much safrer and better returns to be had elsewhere! Good luck!
